title: 110_hr3948
content: The "Share the Sacrifice Act of 2007" establishes a temporary Iraq War surtax under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Establishment of Temporary Iraq War Surtax under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 for taxable year 2008, increasing tax liability for joint returns. For taxable year 2008, a temporary Iraq War Surtax was established under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The surtax increases tax liability for joint returns based on income levels, ranging from 2.5% to 16% of the net income tax liability. For taxable year 2008, a temporary Iraq War Surtax was established under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The surtax increases tax liability for individuals, trusts, and estates based on income levels, with rates ranging from 11% to 16% of the excess income over specific thresholds. For taxable year 2008, a temporary Iraq War Surtax was established under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The surtax increases tax liability based on income levels, with rates ranging from 2.5% to 16% of the excess income over specific thresholds. For taxable year 2008, a temporary Iraq War Surtax was established under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The surtax increases tax liability based on income levels, with rates ranging from 2.5% to 16% of the excess income over specific thresholds. The tax rates are $432.50 plus 11% of the excess over $11,300 for income over $11,300 but not over $18,200, and $1,191.50 plus 16% of the excess over $18,200 for income over $18,200. Additionally, corporations with net income tax liability will have their tax increased by 16 percent. Certain exceptions related to military service apply for individuals. For corporations, the tax imposed under this chapter will be increased by 16 percent of their net income tax liability. Certain exceptions related to military service apply for individuals. Certain exceptions related to military service apply for individuals, including members of the Armed Forces who received excludible compensation under section 112 or death gratuity under chapter 75 of title 10. Members of the Armed Forces or individuals who received a death gratuity under chapter 75 of title 10, United States Code, for a decedent who died on or after September 11, 2001, may be eligible for certain tax exemptions. Members of the Armed Forces or individuals who received a death gratuity under chapter 75 of title 10, United States Code, for a decedent who died on or after September 11, 2001, may be eligible for certain tax exemptions. The taxpayer shall be treated as described in clause (i) or (ii) of subparagraph (A) if either spouse is so described. The taxpayer's net income tax liability is defined as the excess of the regular tax liability, with an exception for individuals with adjusted gross income not exceeding $30,000. The net income tax liability is defined as the excess of the regular tax liability and tax imposed by section 55, minus the credits allowed under part IV, excluding sections 31, 33, and 34. Individuals with adjusted gross income below $30,000 are exempt from this tax. The tax imposed under section 26(b) and section 55 is reduced by credits allowed under part IV, excluding sections 31, 33, and 34. This tax is not considered as part of the regular tax liability for certain purposes. The Temporary Iraq War Surtax, effective after December 31, 2007, does not change tax rates for section 15 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.
